However, the Arab King succeeds in escaping and then invites the Babylonian king to visit his own labyrinth. Later, the Arab king successfully wages war against Babylonia, captures the Babylonian king and subjects him to his labyrinth - a vast, unending desert. The Babylonian king is left to die in the desert, exemplifying the Arab king's labyrinth as a deadly, yet simple, place with no escape.

"The Two Kings and the Two Labyrinths" by Jorge Luis Borges is a tale of two kings, one Babylonian and one Arabian, each with their own interpretation of a labyrinth. The Babylonian king orders the construction of a complex labyrinth to confound the most cautious men. He invites the Arabian king to navigate his labyrinth, intending to belittle him. The Arabian king escapes the maze and promises to show the Babylonian king his own labyrinth. He later conquers Babylonia, captures the Babylonian king, and strands him in the desert, presenting it as his labyrinth - devoid of walls or routes, only endless sand. The Babylonian king ultimately perishes from hunger and thirst. This story highlights the Arabian tradition of designing grand labyrinths.

Title: The Two Kings and the Two Labyrinths [Jorge Luis Borges]

Description: A Babylonian king orders his subjects to build him a labyrinth "so confused and so subtle that the most prudent men would not venture to enter it, and those who did would lose their way." When an Arab king visited his court, the king of Babylonia told him to enter the labyrinth in order to mock him. The Arab king finally managed to get out and told the Babylonian that in his land he had another labyrinth, and Allah willing, he would see that someday the king of Babylonia made its acquaintance." The Arab king returned to his land, and launched an extremely successful attack on the Babylonians, finally capturing the Babylonian King. The Arab tied him on a camel and led him into the desert. After three days of riding, the Arab reminds the Babylonian that he tried to make him lose his way in his labyrinth, and says that he will now show him his, "which has no stairways to climb, nor door to force, nor wearying galleries to wander through, nor walls to impede thy passage." He then untied the Babylonian king, "and abandoned him in the middle of the desert, where he died of hunger and thirst..." Throughout time, Arabian kings have been known to build tremendous labyrinths.
